TITLE I--REAUTHORIZATION OF TRADE ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE PROGRAM; RELATED PROVISIONS

SECTION 101. REAUTHORIZATION OF PROGRAM. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to extend assistance for workers and firms until September 30, 2003. Training limitations under the NAFTA program are also extended until the same date. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to extend assistance for workers and firms until September 30, 2003, with clarifications on regular State unemployment insurance. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2001. AMENDMENTS TO LIMITATIONS ON TRADE READJUSTMENT ALLOWANCES. Amendments to the Trade Act of 1974 include increasing the maximum number of weeks for training programs and providing additional weeks for individuals in need of remedial education. The changes allow for a 130-week period for workers requiring remedial education and increase the weeks from 26 to 52 for training completion. Amendments to the Trade Act of 1974 allow for up to 26 additional weeks of trade readjustment allowances for workers in remedial education programs. Effective January 1, 2001, these changes apply to individuals receiving trade readjustment allowances under the Act. SEC. 103 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to expedite the review of petitions by the Secretary of Labor from 60 days to 40 days. SEC. 104 declares policy and the sense of Congress. Congress reiterates that workers under the trade adjustment assistance program are eligible for various forms of assistance, including transportation, childcare, and healthcare. It is recommended that the Secretary of Labor provide more detailed information on benefit allowances, training, and employment services to workers applying for or certified to receive assistance. The Secretary of Labor should provide detailed information on all available Federal assistance to workers applying for or certified to receive trade adjustment assistance. Establishment of a program by the Secretary of Labor to provide adjustment assistance for workers separated from employment due to the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The Secretary of Labor can receive a petition from a group of workers or their union for certification of eligibility to apply for adjustment assistance. Upon receiving the petition, the Secretary will initiate an investigation and publish a notice in the Federal Register. If requested, a public hearing will be held for interested parties to present evidence and be heard. The Secretary can certify a group of workers for adjustment assistance if a significant number have been separated, sales or production have decreased, and the impact of the 9/11 attacks contributed to the situation. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to worker certifications under this title, with the term "contributed importantly" defined as a significant cause. SEC. 204. BENEFITS.

Workers covered by a certification issued by the Secretary under section 203 shall receive benefits similar to those provided under the Trade Act of 1974.

SEC. 205. ADMINISTRATION.

The administration of the program under this title will follow the provisions of the Trade Act of 1974.

SEC. 206. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 206. DEFINITIONS.

The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Labor. The term "terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001" includes the attacks on the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and the crash in Pennsylvania.

SEC. 207. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. Amounts remain available until expended.
